titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Brian Gilmore papers, 1977-2014 MS2257
titlestmt.author: University Archives, Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

publicationstmt.publisher: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-01-11 11:42:52 -0500.

repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.abstract: This collection containes poems, essays, articles, notebooks, correspondence, fliers, clippings and other materials relating to the literary works of Washington D.C. poet Brian Gilmore. Included are articles from publications including the Washington Post, Detriot Free Press, the Washington Afro American, DC North, the Houston Chronicle and the Progressive as well as research files collected while composing these pieces. Topics include Malcolm X, Duke Ellington, the death penalty, gradutaion rates of athletes, voting rights and critiques of government policies. The material dates from 1977-2014.
did.physloc: Materials are stored off-site, and will require additional retrieval time. Please contact the Special Collections Research Center for more information.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Brian Gilmore, is a poet and writer living in the District of Columbia and Lansing Michigan. His first collection of poetry, "elvis presley is alive and well and living in harlem" was published by THIRD WORLD PRESS of Chicago in 1993. His poetry has appeared in numerous anthologies and he has taught poetry at the Catholic University of America and at Lorton Prison. Brian has published essays in The Nation, The Washington City Paper, The Washington Afro-American, and in "Soulfires: Black Men on Love and Violence". His fiction has been published in Obsidian II and Gargoyle while his book reviews have been widely published in many national publications. He has written for the Christian Science Monitor, The Washington Post, Emerge Magazine, and Africana.com. He has lectured at the Associated Writing Programs Annual Conference (1996 and 1997), Emory University in Atlanta, and has appeared on National Public Radio's "This American Life".

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Please cite unpublished materials in the following way:
Please provide the title and date of item, catalog number (if applicable it will be found written on the folder), name of the collection, name of the repository, and location of the repository.

Example: James Oglethorpe to the Trustees, 13 January 1876, RG0001 Series 1, Box 4, Folder 3. Records of the Board of Trustees, Special Collections Research Center, Gelman Library, The George Washington University, Washington, D.C.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into 5 series: Writings by Brian Gilmore, Writings by other authors, Research materials, Publicity, and Personal files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection containes articles, essays, poetry, research material, correspondence and other materials relating to the works of Washington D.C. poet Brian Gilmore. The material dates from 1977-2014.

Contained within the collection are the multifaceted opinions and views of Brian Gilmore communicated through different types of written media. Poetry, editorials, reviews, articles, essays, and scripts cover topics as diverse as Duke Ellington, capital punishment University basketball, Government reform, Washington D.C. home rule, street violence, poverty, civil rights, and music. The research files allow a researcher the rare chance to view the exact materials that the artist has pulled from in the creation process. The notebooks and unfinished poems provide the opportunity to watch the maturing and editing to which a writer must subject thier work.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: Original donations and Accession from 2014. This arrangement was chosen because the accretion from 2014 could not easily be added to the existing arrangment for this series. Therefore two series were created to maintain the order of the first series, but allow for an understandable arrangement for the second series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains poems, articles and essays written by Brian Gilmore. The material dates from 1988-2012.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Original donation arranged alphabetically by title of work. Accessions that follow the original donation will be organized in accordance with original order and will most likely adhere to the article / poetry split, but will not be interfiled by title aphabetically with the existing collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains poems, articles and essays written by Brian Gilmore. The material dates from 1988-2012.
